Hi @phani_14666 , are you trying to override the Qdrant configuration via the Helm values? To do that, you have to put those settings under the `config:` level in your values.yaml, like this:

```
config:
  service:
    jwt_rbac: true
    ...
```
Everything under `config` will be included directly into the Qdrant config, overriding any other settings: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/configuration/#order-and-priority

Currently our plan to implement the new search architecture revolves around the following strategy:

**Location**: Latitude and Longitude vectorized to search any location, from neighborhoods to cities, streets and even countries.
**Times**: A 168-dimensional binary vector (7 days, 24 hours a day) with 0 for closed time and 1 for open.
**Features it has**: A vector with all the features the establishment has (Cocktails, dinner, payment methods, delivery, etc.)
**Features that it does not have**: Same idea as the previous vector but with the mapped features that the location does not have.
**Reviews**: A vector with all reviews made by users

We are not sure if this is the best way to store this information to perform searches, I am extremely open to suggestions and I really want to fit our new architecture into your solution!!

Hey @null, thanks for your response! I'll add a little more context about how our searches work to help us find the best solution.

During the search flow, users are asked some questions about occasion, expectations and fields to add additional information about what they want to find. So it's very close to a semantic search and we have more data than traditional searches that generally revolve around keywords (thinking about Google's search format today, for example).

So, as it deals with information about the desires of these users, it may happen that data has words and intentions that can be represented by different words, which is why we chose to continue with the vector search instead of classifying a lot of information that could have the same meaning.

An example of this could be something like a user looking for a restaurant and wanting to park their car there. He didn't explicitly say that this location needs to have a parking lot, but I believe that in the vector spectrum this could be positioned close to the information about whether the location has a parking lot, you know?

At the same time, I understand that this type of processing could be done beforehand by an LLM, for example, to be able to transform these search queries into something more standardized.

On the other hand, there is information that we call "fixed" and others that we call "relative". In the case of data about location, opening hours, place name, cuisine, etc., perhaps this type of fixed information, as you said, could be searched through filters? In the case of relative information, it is information generated by users in their experiences in that location, opening up a range of options for what can be done with this information, from categorizing sentiment to generating a set of key words to add to the search.

content: Sure, wanted to understand about these preparations
In qdrant with the default configuration all replicas apply updates in the same time. There is a way to build read-write segregation, but it woul require some preparations

We are running few models which require real time updates. Usually the CPU of this cluster is >10% but during indexing time the CPU spikes to ~60%. No of points in the collection is in the range of 300-500k only.
We want to route these updates to write only nodes and replicate to replica nodes eventually to minimize latency impact on serving/read nodes.

Hi, we are using Qdrant as vector database as part of a RAG system using langroid. We wanted to add qdrant's SPLADE-based sparse retrieval ((ref)[https://qdrant.tech/articles/sparse-vectors/]).

As I understood, the only solution to add it is using each vector as a named vector. So, if we want to use dense+sparse retrieval for a collection, we have to add both dense and sparse as named vectors.

There is an issue of backward compatibility for our use case since we want to use a common code for retrieval from both dense and hybrid collections. If we already have a dense collection (& that's not a named vector), we cannot use the same retrieval code. We wanted to know if there is a workaround to use sparse retrieval along with being compatible for default dense-vector collections.

You can checked the PR I raised to langroid for adding sparse retrieval.
PR: https://github.com/langroid/langroid/pull/450

async def fetch_url(session, id):

    async with session.get(url) as response:
        return await response.text()


async def fetch_all_urls(ids):
    async with aiohttp.ClientSession() as session:
        tasks = [fetch_url(session, id) for id in ids]
        results = await asyncio.gather(*tasks)
        return results


async def main(ids):
    results = await fetch_all_urls(ids)
    print("total requests:", len(ids))


start = time.time()

asyncio.run(main(ids))
print("tital time:", time.time() - start)
```

Technically, when using search there is no true pagination. If you use an offset, qdrant actually needs to search thru the first set of results first in order to reach and return your offset. This is the nature of hnsw, you can read more about this in the qdrant doc. It means that big offsets (large pagination), are very taxing on the system because it keeps redoing big searches each time the user makes a new big pagination call.

It‚Äôs optimal if most users may not select page 2,3,4,5 etc. Because you still expose the ability to get to deep search results while only rarely needing to actually search that deep. But if you expect all your users to be always going deep into the pages, it becomes very expensive for qdrant because it keeps re-searching thru results to get to the latest offset.

So actually, if you expect users to frequently need to paginate thru to deep pages, then your most optimal approach is your original approach with redis üòÇ. In that case. You do one expensive search and then never have to revisit qdrant again, just paginate out of redis cache, which lets you manage load times on your front end. 

You could do it kind of hierarchically if you expect users to paginate thru 1k-2k results. You fetch 1k on first call to qdrant, cache to redis, paginate 100 at a time to user from redis. If the user reaches 1k, you go back to qdrant to do an expensive offset to get 2k.

Qdrant indeed uses available memory as a cache, in general, we recommend to limit the amount of available ram with docker (or k8s) limits

We have a Grafana dashboard monitoring Qdrant memory utilization. It alerts when the container available memory is < 10%. Specifically, we are looking at the `container_memory_rss` metric. 
In the past, we noticed Qdrant would perform poorly when it ran out of memory, so we added this alert as a leading indicator. However, the past few times this alert has gone off, Qdrant was performing normally even though it was using ~95% of available memory. Our workaround at this time is to restart our Qdrant service.
I'm looking for advice on the following:  
1) I'm assuming Qdrant is using all of its available memory as a cache. Is there a way to cap this cache so that it stops growing after some limit?

Otherwise you might have to go back for each new version to update the payload on all your existing points?

In your example you suggest to storage an array/a list of versions per point. But to me it seems to make more sense to tag a point with a single version, and update your query to match a range of versions.
Yes, tagging your points with a version in payload seems to be the right approach here.

All multivalues (lists) in qdrant are handled as if there were multiple fields with the same name. So whatever index you choose will help if it is a multi-value or just a single value. 
For example, if you choose a `"keyword"` index, it will work for both `"my_key": "single_value"` and also `"my_key": ["value_1", "value_2", ...]`
^^ @null

@null  I'll insert 10k chunks (documents) once. They is version 1 of my chatbot. I later add 100 more documents and 1k of existing chunks (documents) are updated. I now want to be able to search version 1 of my chatbot (unaware of 100 more docs & 1k updated chunks). I also want to be able to search version 2 of my chatbot. 
To allow this full versioning I will need to store some versioning information attached to embeddings. To prevent repeatedly inserting the 9k unchanged embeddings, I would like to just reuse the old points and attach some versioning information per point.

The simplest impl. would be to store a versions: [] with every point, where a search would include a (query, version=17), here only including embeddings tagged with version 17.

This of couse would still need to touch every embedding on creation of a new version. Thus another appraoch would be to optimize the common case of a document staying unchanged and relevant: a included_since_version = 17 and included_until_version = 20. In searching, we'd then check (query, version >= included_since_version AND version <= included_until_version). This would result in only needing to touch the diff (100 new, 1k upserts, bumping included_until_version).

An implementation to get all the points with pagination could look like

```python
from qdrant_client import grpc
SCROLL_SIZE = 200

def get_all_points(self, collection_name: str):
    results: List[models.Record] = []
    next_offset = None
    stop_scrolling = False
    while not stop_scrolling:
        records, next_offset = self._client.scroll(
            collection_name,
            limit=SCROLL_SIZE,
            offset=next_offset,
            with_payload=True,
            with_vectors=True,
        )
        stop_scrolling = next_offset is None or (
            isinstance(next_offset, grpc.PointId)
            and next_offset.num == 0
            and next_offset.uuid == ""
        )

        results.extend(records)

    return results
```

Hey @dougatlumen5, with factor of replication of 2 qdrant is supposed to recover from rolling updates, but it actually depends on how exactly you are making them.


First of all, restart should respect the `/readyz` endpoint and don't schedule more than one pod restart at a time.

Second, and that I think might be your case, the node after restart is expected to have the same data as before. Including the consensus parameters, which were persistent there before.
If you are using local disk, I suspect the node starts clean after restart. In this case it won't even be a part of consensus.

content:
Hi Marc. Unfortunately, it is not possible to do this (not with a single request, at least).

The way search works in Qdrant, whatever `limit` you specify, Qdrant will search for that many vectors (however similar or dissimilar they may be) and then sort them by rank. But it's not possible to query exact numbers above particular `score_threshold` for a particular reference vector.

I think the best you could do in this case is either:

- Make a series of `search` requests with increasing `offset`s and scan returned results until you find the one *below* your required `score_threshold`. (Note, I'm not 100% sure if that's a good idea, I'll ping someone else to correct me.)

- Or, if possible, try to design your pagination same way, without a predetermined number of pages, just with increasing `offset`.

I noticed that the sparse vector with an on-disk index was slow when I first interacted with the UI by clicking a button, before any coding intervention. Specifically, I wasn't applying any filters; I was merely using the recommend API with a single ID.

The initial search, prior to cache activation, takes about 8-30 seconds, but once the cache is operational, it drops to 1 second.

When we ran parallel requests with dense vector searches combined with quantization and in-memory processing, they were completed in just a few seconds for 200 parallel requests. However, it took 2.5 minutes for the sparse search with an on-disk index.

We initially set the EBS throughput at 125MB/s, but even after boosting it to 1000MB/s, the first search still took around 8 seconds.
Please note that you should also configure payload indexes when using payload filtering.

We get a decent latency of ~70-120ms with multiple filters with HNSW on_disk. Scale ~680M points. 
moving HNSW to RAM should drastically increase the RAM consumption.

I'd recommend this:
- `on_disk: true` for vectors
- remove `on_disk: true` for HNSW config (keeping it in memory will greatly improve search performance)
- remove `memmap_threshold` because you already set `on_disk`
If you set `on_disk: true` for vectors, the vectors will be on disk.
If you set `on_disk: true` for the HNSW config, the index will be on disk.
It depends on how you configure it.
It basically will store the index on_disk?

> Will on_disk for vectors affect the latency?
Yes.

Followup: Will on_disk for vectors affect the latency?
If you think you have enough RAM to keep everything in memory, you're likley better off disabling all on-disk flags.

> on_disk=true is present in collection config
I don't see it.

It should be set for the vector configuration, not for the HNSW config. Also, you'll likely want  to disable `memmap_threshold` because it's obsolete if setting `on_disk: true`.
